questions.text: A newly-wed 22-year-old woman has started taking Mala N as an oral contraceptive. However, on her honeymoon, she forgets to carry the packet and as a result, she misses 4 consecutive days of the tablet and reports to you the next day, on Day 15 of the tablet. What is the next best step?

options.label: A
options.text: Take the 4 missed pills, continue the packet, take the emergency pill and use a condom for the next 7 days

options.label: B
options.text: Take the last pill, continue the remaining hormonal pills, take the emergency pill, use a condom and then discard the iron pills and start a new pack immediately

options.label: C
options.text: Take the 4 missed pills, continue the packet, take the emergency pill and use a condom for the next 7 days

options.label: D
options.text: Discard the remaining tablets and start a new pack immediately, use emergency pill and use a condom for 7 days

questions.correct_answer: C. Take the 4 missed pills, continue the packet, take the emergency pill and use a condom for the next 7 days
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Take the last missed pill, continue the packet, take the emergency pill and use a condom for the next 7 days

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ When a woman misses 3 or more hormonal contraceptive pills in the first 14 days of her cycle, she should take the last missed pill, continue with the current pack, use emergency contraception if needed, and use backup contraception (e.g., condoms) for the next 7 days to prevent pregnancy.

questions.text: A 34-year-old P1 presents to the gynae OPD. She has been using injection Antara for contraception but is now worried that she may have become pregnant as she missed the last dose and has now presented 3 weeks after she was supposed to get the last dose. What is the next best step?

options.label: B
options.text: Do a UPT, give inj Antara

options.label: C
options.text: Do a UPT, give emergency pill, give inj Antara

options.label: D
options.text: Do a UPT, give emergency pill, give inj Antara and advise a condom for 7 days

questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Give injection Antara

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ When a patient presents up to 4 weeks late for her scheduled DMPA injection (Antara), it is safe to administer the injection without requiring a UPT or additional contraception, based on Government of India guidelines.

questions.text: A 24-year-old P1L1 has heard about the Implanon NXT and wants to get it inserted. The only absolute contraindication to this contraceptive method is:

options.label: D
options.text: Immediate postpartum in a lactating woman

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Breast cancer

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Breast cancer is an absolute contraindication for any hormonal contraceptive method, including both estrogen-containing and progesterone-only options such as Implanon NXT. Progestin can stimulate growth in progesterone receptor-positive breast cancers, making it unsafe for patients with a history of or current breast cancer.

questions.text: A woman who has been using Chhaya as a contraceptive for 2 months has missed a week's medicine. What is the next best step?

options.label: A
options.text: Take the last missed pill as soon as possible; continue the pills as scheduled

options.label: B
options.text: Continue the normal schedule but use a condom for 7 days

options.label: C
options.text: Take the last missed pill and use a condom for 7 days

options.label: D
options.text: Take the emergency pill (LNG), use a condom for 7 days

questions.correct_answer: B. Continue the normal schedule but use a condom for 7 days
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Continue the normal schedule but use a condom for 7 days

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ If a woman misses her Chhaya (Centchroman) contraceptive for less than seven days, she should continue taking the pills as per the normal schedule but use a backup method such as condoms for the next 7 days to ensure contraceptive effectiveness. Emergency contraception is not required in this case.

questions.text: A Long-Acting Reversible Contraceptive is one in which the frequency of administration is less than:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Once a month

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ LARCs are contraceptives that require administration or replacement less frequently than once a month, making them highly effective and convenient for long-term use. Examples include IUDs, subdermal implants, and injectable contraceptives.

questions.text: The GATHER approach is used for
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Contraceptive counseling

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The GATHER approach is a client-centered counseling strategy used in contraceptive counseling to ensure that individuals make informed and voluntary decisions about their reproductive health, with full understanding of the methods available to them.

questions.text: The instrument shown below is primarily used for?

options.label: B
options.text: Holding the cervical lip during vaginal surgeries

options.label: C
options.text: Inserting a post placental intra-uterine device

options.label: D
options.text: Holding the edges of the uterine scar in a cesarean section

questions.correct_answer: C. Inserting a post placental intra-uterine device
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Inserting a post placental intra-uterine device

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Kelly's forceps are primarily used for inserting a post-placental intrauterine device (PPIUCD) due to their design, which allows for secure handling of the device without causing trauma to intrauterine tissues. The absence of a locking mechanism and the fenestrated tip make them suitable for this procedure.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents to the emergency at 32 weeks of pregnancy. She has a history of preterm vaginal delivery due to pre-eclampsia in a previous pregnancy, and this pregnancy has been uneventful until now. She complains of abdominal pain and reduced fetal movements for 1 day. On examination, the uterus is at the xiphisternum, tense, and tender to touch. The fetal parts are not well felt, and the fetal heart rate cannot be auscultated. Her BP is 120/80 mmHg, and her pulse rate is 120 bpm. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Abruptio placentae

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Placental abruption should be suspected in pregnant women who present with severe abdominal pain, a tender and tense uterus, absent fetal movements, and fetal heart rate abnormalities. It is a life-threatening condition requiring immediate delivery to prevent maternal complications such as hemorrhage and coagulopathy.

questions.text: A 30-year-old primigravida presents at 32 weeks to the OPD for a routine checkup. She has no complaints. On examination, the uterus is slightly above the umbilicus, and the symphysiofundal height (SFH) is 27 cm. The fetal parts cannot be felt well. The fetal heart rate (FHR) is heard clearly at 150 bpm. What is the expected finding on the ultrasound?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) AFI – 4

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of reduced symphysiofundal height (SFH) and difficulty palpating fetal parts, oligohydramnios should be suspected, and an amniotic fluid index (AFI) below 5 cm confirms the diagnosis. Oligohydramnios can result in intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR) and other complications, making early detection crucial.

questions.text: A 29-year-old G2 whose blood group is B negative presents to the OPD. Her husband's blood group is A positive. She is 28 weeks pregnant, and her Indirect Coombs Test (ICT) is reported to be 1:32. She recalls receiving Anti-D after her first delivery. What is the next best step?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Order an MCA-PSV Doppler

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In Rh-negative pregnant women with a critical ICT titer (≥1:16), the next step is to assess fetal well-being using MCA-PSV Doppler to evaluate for fetal anemia. Early detection of anemia allows timely intervention to prevent complications like hydrops fetalis and fetal death.

questions.text: A 19-year-old primigravida presents to the emergency at 29 weeks gestation with a history of seizures for the past hour. On examination, she is disoriented, her BP is 150/100 mmHg, the abdominal exam reveals a uterus consistent with 28 weeks, and the fetal heart rate (FHR) is 130 bpm. What is the next best step?

options.label: C
options.text: IV phenytoin + IV hydralazine + Induction of labor

options.label: D
options.text: MgSO4 + IV labetalol + Induction of labor

questions.correct_answer: D. MgSO4 + IV labetalol + Induction of labor
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) MgSO4 + IV labetalol + Induction of labor

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The primary management of eclampsia involves controlling seizures with magnesium sulfate, controlling blood pressure with antihypertensives, and immediate delivery (via induction or cesarean if indicated). Corticosteroids can be administered if there is time, but the maternal condition dictates the urgency of delivery.
  • ➤ immediate delivery

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to the OPD. She has been diagnosed with a monochorionic diamniotic twin pregnancy and is now 28 weeks pregnant. An ultrasound reveals the following image. What is your diagnosis?
questions.correct_answer: D. Twin to twin transfusion syndrome
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS) occurs in monochorionic diamniotic twin pregnancies when there is an imbalance of blood flow between the two fetuses. This condition is characterized by one twin developing oligohydramnios (donor) and the other developing polyhydramnios (recipient). Prompt recognition and management are crucial to improve outcomes for both fetuses.
  • ➤ Twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS)

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman who has recently undergone a renal transplant is keen on conceiving. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding pregnancy in a renal transplant recipient?

options.label: A
options.text: Leflunomide is absolutely contra-indicated in pregnancy

options.label: B
options.text: She should wait at least 2 years following the transplant before getting pregnant

options.label: C
options.text: Vaginal delivery is the preferred route of delivery

options.label: D
options.text: The risk of pre-eclampsia is not increased in renal transplant recipients

questions.correct_answer: D. The risk of pre-eclampsia is not increased in renal transplant recipients
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) The risk of pre-eclampsia is not increased in renal transplant recipients

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In renal transplant recipients, pregnancy is feasible but carries increased risks such as pre-eclampsia, hypertension, and preterm labor . Immunosuppressive drugs like leflunomide, cyclophosphamide, and methotrexate are contraindicated in pregnancy. Post-transplant, women are advised to wait 1–2 years before attempting pregnancy to ensure stable graft function and optimal maternal outcomes.
  • ➤ pre-eclampsia, hypertension, and preterm labor
  • ➤ leflunomide, cyclophosphamide, and methotrexate

questions.text: Asymptomatic bacteruria in pregnancy is defined as:

options.label: A
options.text: The presence of ≥1 bacterial species that has a count ≥10 5 CFUs /mL in a urine culture of a voided specimen

options.label: B
options.text: The presence of ≥ 5 pus cells in a mid-stream urine routine sample

options.label: C
options.text: The presence of ≥1 bacterial species that has a count ≥10 3 CFUs /mL in a urine culture of a voided specimen

options.label: D
options.text: The presence of ≥ 10 pus cells in a mid-stream urine routine sample

questions.correct_answer: A. The presence of ≥1 bacterial species that has a count ≥10 5 CFUs /mL in a urine culture of a voided specimen
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) The presence of ≥1 bacterial species that has a count ≥105CFUs /mL in  a urine culture of a voided specimen

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Asymptomatic bacteriuria in pregnancy is defined as ≥10⁵ CFUs/mL in a urine culture, and it is critical to screen and treat this condition during pregnancy to prevent complications such as pyelonephritis, preterm birth, and IUGR.
  • ➤ ≥10⁵ CFUs/mL

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with a history of recurrent mid-trimester losses. Which of the following is least likely?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Fetal chromosomal anomalies

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For recurrent mid-trimester pregnancy losses, always consider anatomical causes (such as septate uterus or submucosal fibroids), cervical insufficiency , or immunologic causes like APLA syndrome . Chromosomal anomalies are more commonly implicated in isolated first-trimester losses.
  • ➤ anatomical causes
  • ➤ cervical insufficiency
  • ➤ immunologic causes
  • ➤ APLA syndrome

questions.text: A 24-year-old primigravida presents at 20 weeks with acute abdominal pain. Ultrasound and Doppler reveal an ovarian torsion. What is the best management option?

options.label: D
options.text: MTP followed by laparoscopy and detorsion

questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Laparoscopy and detorsion

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ovarian torsion in pregnancy is a surgical emergency that is best managed by laparoscopy and detorsion . Prompt intervention can preserve ovarian function, prevent necrosis, and reduce complications, without needing to terminate the pregnancy.
  • ➤ laparoscopy and detorsion

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presents with painful vesicular genital lesions at 38 weeks and is in labor. What is the next best step?

options.label: A
options.text: Augment, cut short 2nd stage with forceps, avoid episiotomy

options.label: B
options.text: Augment, cut short 2nd stage with vacuum, avoid episiotomy

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Emergency cesarean section

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a pregnant woman with active genital herpes lesions during labor, an emergency cesarean section is the recommended management to prevent neonatal herpes. Vaginal delivery is contraindicated due to the high risk of transmission of the herpes virus to the neonate.
  • ➤ emergency cesarean section

questions.text: The mechanism of action of Atosiban is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Oxytocin receptor antagonist

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Atosiban is an oxytocin receptor antagonist used to suppress preterm labor by inhibiting oxytocin-induced uterine contractions.
  • ➤ Atosiban
  • ➤ oxytocin receptor antagonist

questions.text: Fetal growth restriction will not show the following Doppler finding?

options.label: B
options.text: Decreased flow in the umbilical Artery

options.label: C
options.text: Increased resistance in the uterine Artery

questions.correct_answer: A. Decreased flow in the MCA
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Decreased flow in the MCA

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In fetal growth restriction (FGR), increased flow in the MCA is typically seen due to the brain-sparing effect, and thus decreased flow in the MCA is not a finding associated with FGR.

questions.text: A 23-year-old primigravida complains of decreased fetal movements at 38 weeks. An NST is done. She is then sent for an ultrasound to complete the biophysical profile. Which is not an ultrasound component of the Biophysical Profile (BPP)?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Fetal heart rate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a biophysical profile (BPP) , fetal heart rate is evaluated by the Non-Stress Test (NST) , while the ultrasound assesses fetal breathing movements , fetal tone , fetal movement , and amniotic fluid volume .
  • ➤ biophysical profile (BPP)
  • ➤ fetal heart rate
  • ➤ Non-Stress Test (NST)
  • ➤ fetal breathing movements
  • ➤ fetal tone
  • ➤ fetal movement
  • ➤ amniotic fluid volume

questions.text: Which is not a routine antenatal test?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) TORCH

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ TORCH screening is not a routine antenatal test and is only performed if there is a clinical indication or concern for infections such as Toxoplasmosis, Rubella, Cytomegalovirus, or Herpes during pregnancy.

questions.text: A 32-year-old G3 is advised a Fetal ECHO at 24 weeks. Which is not an indication for a fetal ECHO?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Gestational diabetes mellitus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Gestational diabetes mellitus is not a routine indication for a fetal ECHO unless it is poorly controlled or associated with other risk factors. Conditions such as maternal phenylketonuria, Anti-Ro antibodies, and carbamazepine exposure all increase the risk of fetal heart abnormalities, justifying the need for fetal echocardiography.
  • ➤ Indications for fetal ECHO
  • ➤ Indications for fetal ECHO
  • ➤ F: suspected Fetal cardiac anomaly Chromosomal anomaly E: Either parent with CHD/ Prev baby with CHD T: Teratogenic agent exposure (Li) A: Arrythmia L: Anti-La/ anti-Ro E: Extra cardiac anomaly C: Conception by IVF/ Ketonuria (Phenyl) H: Hydrops O: Overt Diabetes
  • ➤ F: suspected Fetal cardiac anomaly Chromosomal anomaly
  • ➤ E: Either parent with CHD/ Prev baby with CHD
  • ➤ T: Teratogenic agent exposure (Li)
  • ➤ A: Arrythmia
  • ➤ L: Anti-La/ anti-Ro
  • ➤ E: Extra cardiac anomaly
  • ➤ C: Conception by IVF/ Ketonuria (Phenyl)
  • ➤ H: Hydrops
  • ➤ O: Overt Diabetes

questions.text: A 38-year-old primigravida is informed that her risk of Down syndrome is significantly high due to her age. The patient asks for a screening test with a high detection rate. What is the test that you will advise her?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Cell-free DNA

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cell-free DNA (cfDNA) testing is the most accurate non-invasive screening method for detecting Down syndrome and other chromosomal abnormalities, with a detection rate exceeding 99%. It should be considered for high-risk patients, such as those of advanced maternal age.

questions.text: The dietary requirement of a 24-year-old primigravida with a BMI of 24 at 24 weeks is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 340 Kcal/day

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ During the second trimester, a primigravida with a normal BMI (18.5–24.9) should increase her caloric intake by approximately 340 kcal/day to meet the nutritional demands of pregnancy.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman visits the OPD for pre-conceptual counseling with a history of undergoing an MTP in her earlier pregnancy due to an anomaly. She only has the ultrasound image done at 20 weeks. Which drug could have possibly caused this?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Telmisartan

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Drugs such as ACE inhibitors and ARBs, including Telmisartan, can lead to anhydramnios in the second or third trimester of pregnancy. Anhydramnios can result in serious complications, including pulmonary hypoplasia, limb deformities, and facial flattening, all of which may result in a poor prognosis for the fetus.

questions.text: Which vaccine is absolutely contra-indicated in pregnancy?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) HPV vaccine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The HPV vaccine is contraindicated during pregnancy, as it is not recommended due to insufficient safety data. Vaccines like inactivated influenza, rabies, and COVID vaccines are safe and recommended for pregnant women under certain circumstances.

questions.text: Quadruple marker includes all except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Unconjugated estradiol

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The quadruple marker test measures four markers in maternal blood: alpha-fetoprotein, inhibin-A, human chorionic gonadotropin, and unconjugated estriol. Unconjugated estradiol is not a component of this test.
  • ➤ not

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presents to the OPD. This is her 4th pregnancy. She had an MTP at 18 weeks due to a fetal anomaly in her 1st pregnancy. Her 2nd pregnancy was a preterm twin delivery at 32 weeks, and she had a spontaneous abortion at 8 weeks in her 3rd pregnancy. She is currently 34 weeks. Her parity index is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) G4P1A2

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Gravida refers to the total number of pregnancies, and Para refers to the number of pregnancies that crossed the threshold of viability (around 28 weeks), regardless of the number of fetuses. Abortions include both spontaneous and elective terminations before 28 weeks.

questions.text: The Estimated date of delivery in an IVF conception is how many weeks following the embryo transfer?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 38 weeks

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In IVF pregnancies, the estimated date of delivery is generally 38 weeks after the embryo transfer. This takes into account the artificial initiation of pregnancy through embryo implantation.
  • ➤ 38 weeks

questions.text: Pre-eclampsia screening is recommended at which gestational age?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 11-14 weeks

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pre-eclampsia screening is recommended between 11-14 weeks of gestation, as early detection allows for preventive interventions like low-dose aspirin, which can reduce the risk of developing pre-eclampsia.
  • ➤ 11-14 weeks

questions.text: In the screening of gestational diabetes mellitus by the DIPSI guidelines, all are correct except:

options.label: B
options.text: A 2h sample is taken after asking her to drink 75g glucose mixed in water

options.label: D
options.text: The glucose mixture is to be drunk over 10 mins

questions.correct_answer: A. The patient is called fasting
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) The patient is called fasting

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The DIPSI guidelines for gestational diabetes mellitus screening do not require fasting ; the test can be done in a non-fasting state with a 75g oral glucose load, and a 2-hour post-load blood sample is measured.
  • ➤ not require fasting

questions.text: The instrument shown in the image is used in which scenario?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Postpartum hemorrhage

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Jada system is used to manage atonic postpartum hemorrhage , applying negative pressure to encourage uterine contraction and stop excessive bleeding. It is part of the mechanical interventions for PPH when uterotonics or other first-line treatments are not sufficient.
  • ➤ Jada system
  • ➤ atonic postpartum hemorrhage

questions.text: Which is not a component of the Modified Bishop Score?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Cervical stretching

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Modified Bishop Score assesses cervical readiness for labor induction using factors such as cervical dilation, effacement, consistency, position, and fetal station. "Cervical stretching" is not part of this scoring system.

questions.text: The WHO's labor care guide (LCG), also known as the next-generation partograph, has brought about many changes in the existing intrapartum care. Which of the following is not a component of the LCG?

options.label: B
options.text: Encouraging supportive care, pain management and ambulation in labor

options.label: C
options.text: Emphasizing the need for stricter timelines by re-enforcing the alert and action lines

questions.correct_answer: C. Emphasizing the need for stricter timelines by re-enforcing the alert and action lines
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Emphasizing the need for stricter timelines by re-enforcing the alert and action lines

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The WHO's Labor Care Guide promotes flexibility in labor monitoring, focusing on supportive care and acknowledging natural variations in labor progression. It does not enforce stricter timelines or use the traditional alert and action lines found in earlier partographs.

questions.text: A baby is born as shown to a 26-year-old primigravida. What is the likely complication associated with this type of birth?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Perineal tears

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The occiput posterior position often leads to a more difficult delivery and is associated with an increased risk of perineal tears due to the increased pressure exerted on the perineum as the baby’s head passes through the birth canal.
  • ➤ perineal tears

questions.text: A 32-year-old G3 is in the labor room at 39 weeks. Following delivery of the baby, the placenta is attempted to be delivered, during which the resident notes that she can no longer palpate the uterine fundus. An immediate attempt is made to replace the uterus. What complication can happen because of this?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Neurogenic shock

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Uterine inversion is a serious obstetric emergency that can lead to neurogenic shock due to vagal stimulation. Immediate management is essential, including manual replacement of the uterus, and the patient may require supportive care to stabilize blood pressure and heart rate.
  • ➤ neurogenic shock

questions.text: Cord prolapse occurs highest in which malpresentation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Transverse lie

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cord prolapse is most likely to occur in a transverse lie , where there is no part of the fetus adequately filling the cervix, increasing the risk of the umbilical cord slipping through and getting compressed.
  • ➤ Cord prolapse
  • ➤ transverse lie

questions.text: A partogram of a woman in labor is shown below. Oxytocin infusion has been administered. Mark the best management for the patient:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Cesarean section

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases where there is fetal distress and failure of labor progression, despite adequate contractions, the most appropriate management is cesarean section to ensure the safety of both the mother and the baby.
  • ➤ cesarean section

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant G3P2L2 woman presented to the OBG department at 36 weeks of amenorrhea. Ultrasound shows that the fetus is in oblique lie. The liquor is adequate, the placenta is normal, and she has no gross anomaly. Both her previous deliveries were normal vaginal deliveries. What is the best management?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) External cephalic version

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ At 36 weeks with an oblique lie , External Cephalic Version (ECV) is the recommended management, particularly when there is adequate amniotic fluid, no placental or fetal anomalies, and the woman has had successful vaginal deliveries in the past.
  • ➤ 36 weeks
  • ➤ oblique lie
  • ➤ External Cephalic Version (ECV)

questions.text: A pregnant woman at 38 weeks of gestation is planned for an elective cesarean section in view of breech presentation. She has not had any complications but presents to you with complaints of feeling light-headedness and dizziness when she lies on her back. What precaution should be taken at the time of cesarean section?

options.label: A
options.text: Avoiding oxytocin at birth of the baby

options.label: B
options.text: Avoiding methylergometrine at birth of baby

options.label: C
options.text: Putting a wedge under the right hip before starting the caesarean

options.label: D
options.text: IV colloids at the time of anaesthesia

questions.correct_answer: C. Putting a wedge under the right hip before starting the caesarean
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Putting a wedge under the right hip before starting the cesarean

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In patients experiencing supine hypotensive syndrome , placing a wedge under the right hip to achieve a left lateral tilt is crucial to prevent hypotension caused by the compression of the inferior vena cava. This precaution is especially important during cesarean sections when spinal anesthesia can further lower blood pressure.
  • ➤ supine hypotensive syndrome
  • ➤ wedge under the right hip

questions.text: A G2P1 presents at 28 weeks. On examination, the uterus is 24 weeks. On ultrasound, there is absent liquor. Which could be the most likely cause?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Fetal posterior urethral valve

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of oligohydramnios or absent amniotic fluid, conditions that obstruct fetal urine production or outflow, such as posterior urethral valve , are the most likely causes. This condition leads to a significant reduction in amniotic fluid, which is primarily composed of fetal urine after mid-pregnancy.
  • ➤ oligohydramnios
  • ➤ posterior urethral valve

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presents with her second pregnancy at 10 weeks. She gives a history of developing pre-eclampsia at 28 weeks in her first pregnancy, ultimately leading to a preterm delivery at 32 weeks. She is very anxious and asks if this can develop again and how to prevent it. You explain to her that there was a problem in the development of maternal-fetal circulation in early pregnancy and prescribe the following:

options.label: A
options.text: Low dose aspirin 75mg to be started after 16 weeks

options.label: B
options.text: Low dose aspirin 75mg to be started before 16 weeks

options.label: C
options.text: Low dose aspirin 75mg + LMWH to be started after 16 weeks

options.label: D
options.text: Low dose aspirin 75mg + LMWH to be started before 16 weeks

questions.correct_answer: B. Low dose aspirin 75mg to be started before 16 weeks
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Low dose aspirin 75 mg to be started before 16 weeks

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For the prevention of early-onset pre-eclampsia , low-dose aspirin should be started before 16 weeks of gestation, ideally around 10-12 weeks. LMWH is not routinely used for pre-eclampsia prevention unless there is an underlying thrombophilic condition like APLA .
  • ➤ early-onset pre-eclampsia
  • ➤ low-dose aspirin
  • ➤ before 16 weeks
  • ➤ APLA

questions.text: A 22-year-old primigravida is in labor. Following an ARM (artificial rupture of membranes), she becomes extremely breathless and her pulse and BP are unrecordable. Immediate resuscitation is started, following which the patient is stabilized and shifted to the ICU. What is a possible cause?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Amniotic fluid embolism

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Amniotic fluid embolism (AFE) should be suspected in cases of sudden cardiovascular collapse during or shortly after labor, particularly following rupture of membranes. Early recognition and prompt resuscitation are critical to improving outcomes.
  • ➤ Amniotic fluid embolism (AFE)

questions.text: A primigravida is in the 2nd stage of labor for 2 hours with good uterine contractions. On examination, the head is 1/5th palpable. Fetal heart rate (FHR) is 140 bpm. On vaginal examination, the cervix is fully dilated; the head is at the ischial spines in ROT position. Caput is ++ and moulding is ++. How will you deliver her?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Emergency LSCS

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ When labor is arrested in the second stage, with signs of obstructed labor (caput and moulding) and no further descent of the fetal head despite adequate contractions, the safest option is an emergency cesarean section to avoid fetal and maternal complications.
  • ➤ emergency cesarean section

questions.text: Identify the plane colored orange in the image:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Least dimension

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The plane of least pelvic dimensions is essential in the birthing process, as it is the narrowest passage the fetus must navigate during delivery.
  • ➤ plane of least pelvic dimensions

questions.text: A 37-year-old G1 presents at 18 weeks for her routine targeted fetal anomaly ultrasound. The fetal anatomy appears normal, but the cervical length is 15mm. What is the next best step?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Vaginal progesterone

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a woman with a short cervix (<25 mm) in the second trimester without a history of preterm birth or miscarriage, vaginal progesterone is the best management to reduce the risk of preterm labor. Cervical cerclage is reserved for women with a significant history of cervical insufficiency.
  • ➤ vaginal progesterone

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents to the OPD at 6 weeks. Her urine pregnancy test is positive. She has no complaints. A TVS (transvaginal ultrasound) shows a normal uterus with an endometrial thickness of 12 mm. Both adnexa are unremarkable. A serum beta hCG shows a value of 426, and a repeat serum beta hCG after 48 hours shows a value of 902. Which is the correct statement?

options.label: A
options.text: This is likely an ectopic pregnancy and a repeat TVS is urgently needed

options.label: B
options.text: This is likely an ectopic pregnancy and she required immediated laparoscopy

options.label: C
options.text: This is likely an intra – uterine pregnancy and a TVS should be done when beta hCG is 1500 IU

options.label: D
options.text: This is likely an intra – uterine pregnancy and a TVS should be done when beta hCG is 6000 IU

questions.correct_answer: C. This is likely an intra – uterine pregnancy and a TVS should be done when beta hCG is 1500 IU
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) This is likely an intra-uterine pregnancy and a TVS should be done when beta hCG is 1500 IU

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In early pregnancy, a TVS should be repeated when the beta hCG level reaches around 1500 IU , as this is the discriminatory zone at which an intrauterine pregnancy should be visible on ultrasound. An appropriate rise in beta hCG levels over 48 hours, as seen here, suggests an intrauterine pregnancy.
  • ➤ beta hCG level
  • ➤ 1500 IU

questions.text: A 34-year-old G2P1 presents at 36 weeks. She has no complaints and is appreciating fetal movements well. She had a previous classical cesarean at 25 weeks for eclampsia and severe FGR. She is currently on low-dose aspirin and prenatal vitamins. On examination, the uterus is term and FHR is 140 bpm. An ultrasound reveals a single live fetus in breech presentation, placenta posterior, and normal amniotic fluid volume. The patient desires a vaginal delivery. What is the best management option?

options.label: A
options.text: Wait for her to go into spontaneous labor

options.label: D
options.text: Review at 40 weeks, if still not turned, schedule an elective cesarean

questions.correct_answer: B. Schedule an elective cesarean section
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Schedule an elective cesarean section

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a patient with a previous classical cesarean section , the risk of uterine rupture during labor is high, and thus a repeat elective cesarean section is the safest option. Vaginal delivery, including external cephalic version, is contraindicated in this scenario.
  • ➤ previous classical cesarean section
  • ➤ repeat elective cesarean section

questions.text: A 22-year-old primigravida is overdue by 2 weeks. Her UPT is positive. She visits the OPD with complaints of vaginal bleeding and right-sided abdominal pain. On examination, her vitals are stable. A bimanual examination reveals a bulky, soft uterus and a right adnexal mass which is mildly tender. A TVS shows a right tubal ectopic pregnancy of 4.5 cm with no cardiac activity seen. Beta hCG is 2900 IU. The next best step is?

options.label: D
options.text: Wait and watch while explaining the danger signs

questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Laparoscopy and proceed

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In patients with a confirmed ectopic pregnancy larger than 4 cm , the recommended treatment is surgical management via laparoscopy , especially if there is no cardiac activity and the risk of rupture is significant. Methotrexate is typically reserved for smaller, unruptured ectopic pregnancies.
  • ➤ 4 cm
  • ➤ surgical management via laparoscopy

questions.text: A G3P2L2 presents at 8 weeks for termination of pregnancy by medical methods. Which is not a method of MTP at this gestational age?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Methotrexate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ While Methotrexate + Misoprostol has been used for medical termination in certain regions, it is not commonly recommended, particularly when other more effective methods like Mifepristone + Misoprostol are available. Letrozole + Misoprostol is a newly approved option according to the 2023 WHO guidelines.
  • ➤ Methotrexate + Misoprostol
  • ➤ Mifepristone + Misoprostol
  • ➤ Letrozole + Misoprostol

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman who delivered 18 months ago and is breastfeeding seeks contraceptive advice. Her periods are irregular and heavy. The best contraceptive for her would be?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Mala-N

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a woman who is breastfeeding and has irregular and heavy periods , a combined oral contraceptive pill like Mala-N is appropriate after 6 months postpartum. It helps regulate the menstrual cycle and reduces bleeding while providing effective contraception.
  • ➤ breastfeeding
  • ➤ irregular and heavy periods
  • ➤ combined oral contraceptive pill
  • ➤ Mala-N

questions.text: Which is not a contraindication to this device?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Menstruation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Mirena IUD is not contraindicated during menstruation. It is effective in managing heavy periods and can be inserted at different points during the menstrual cycle. However, conditions like large submucosal fibroids or active trophoblastic disease are contraindications due to the risks of device placement and potential complications.
  • ➤ Mirena IUD
  • ➤ large submucosal fibroids
  • ➤ active trophoblastic disease

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman presents with a right ovarian mass. A laparoscopic ovariectomy was done and the specimen was sent to the pathologist. The image shown on microscopy was seen. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Granulosa cell tumor

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The presence of Call-Exner bodies on histopathology is a key feature of granulosa cell tumors . These tumors are sex cord-stromal in origin and commonly present with an ovarian mass in middle-aged women. They are associated with estrogen production and can lead to symptoms like abnormal uterine bleeding.
  • ➤ Call-Exner bodies
  • ➤ granulosa cell tumors

questions.text: A female patient has a history of three miscarriages. What is the diagnosis based on the image?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Unicornuate uterus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A unicornuate uterus is a congenital anomaly where only one side of the uterus develops properly. This condition can lead to recurrent pregnancy loss, as the uterine cavity is smaller and less suitable for carrying a pregnancy to term. HSG is a diagnostic tool used to identify such anomalies.
  • ➤ unicornuate uterus

questions.text: You are posted in the Gyn OT and arrive late. On entering the OT, you see an endoscopic procedure being done with this image shown on the monitor. Identify the procedure being done:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Hysteroscopic septal resection

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hysteroscopic septal resection is the treatment for a uterine septum, a congenital anomaly that can lead to pregnancy loss. This procedure is performed endoscopically using a hysteroscope to visualize and remove the septum within the uterine cavity.
  • ➤ Hysteroscopic septal resection

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman who is anxious to conceive comes to the OPD with complaints of profuse white vaginal discharge for 2 days. There is no itching, and her menstrual cycles are regular. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Physiological

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Physiological vaginal discharge is normal and can fluctuate during different phases of the menstrual cycle. It is typically clear or white, odorless, and not associated with symptoms like itching or irritation.
  • ➤ Physiological vaginal discharge

questions.text: A 25-year-old primigravida is on indomethacin (25 mg TDS) for polyhydramnios until 35 weeks. What abnormality can the fetus have if she goes into labor now?

options.label: C
options.text: Premature closure of the ductus arteriosus

options.label: D
options.text: Premature closure of the ductus venosus

questions.correct_answer: C. Premature closure of the ductus arteriosus
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Premature closure of the ductus arteriosus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Indomethacin, when used in pregnancy, especially after 32 weeks, can lead to premature closure of the ductus arteriosus , a serious fetal complication. Therefore, its use is typically limited or stopped before the late third trimester to prevent this risk.
  • ➤ premature closure of the ductus arteriosus

questions.text: A patient presents with 3 months of amenorrhea and a positive pregnancy test. Based on the ultrasound image, what would be the possible chromosomal abnormality?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 46 XX

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A complete molar pregnancy is typically associated with a 46 XX karyotype , resulting from the fertilization of an empty egg by a sperm that duplicates its genetic material. The characteristic ultrasound appearance is a "snowstorm" pattern, which is diagnostic of this condition.
  • ➤ complete molar pregnancy
  • ➤ 46 XX karyotype

questions.text: Identify this instrument:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Trocar and cannula

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The trocar and cannula are essential instruments in laparoscopic surgery, used to create access points in the abdominal wall for the introduction of laparoscopic tools such as cameras or surgical instruments.
  • ➤ trocar and cannula

questions.text: A patient is being evaluated for urinary incontinence following a hysterectomy. In the 3-swab test, the upper swab is stained with urine and the middle swab is stained with dye. What is the diagnosis?
questions.correct_answer: A. Uretero-vaginal fistula and vesico-vaginal fistula
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Uretero-vaginal fistula and vesico-vaginal fistula

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The 3-swab test is used to help diagnose the location of urinary fistulas. Urine staining the upper swab suggests a uretero-vaginal fistula , and dye on the middle swab indicates a vesico-vaginal fistula . This pattern suggests leakage from both the ureter and the bladder.
  • ➤ 3-swab test
  • ➤ upper swab
  • ➤ uretero-vaginal fistula
  • ➤ middle swab
  • ➤ vesico-vaginal fistula

questions.text: The drug used in chemoradiation in cervical cancer:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Cisplatin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cisplatin is the preferred chemotherapeutic agent in chemoradiation for locally advanced cervical cancer. It acts synergistically with radiation therapy to improve survival rates.
  • ➤ Cisplatin
  • ➤ chemoradiation

questions.text: Which is not a risk factor for endometrial cancer?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) LNG-IUD

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The LNG-IUD is protective against endometrial cancer due to the local release of progesterone , which counteracts the effects of estrogen on the endometrium. In contrast, high BMI, tamoxifen use, and nulliparity are all associated with increased risks of developing endometrial cancer.
  • ➤ LNG-IUD
  • ➤ local release of progesterone

questions.text: What hormones are secreted by the Leydig cells and the Sertoli cells, respectively?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Testosterone and AMH

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Leydig cells secrete testosterone , while Sertoli cells secrete Anti-Müllerian Hormone (AMH) during development and inhibin in adulthood, which regulates FSH secretion.
  • ➤ Leydig cells
  • ➤ testosterone
  • ➤ Sertoli cells
  • ➤ Anti-Müllerian Hormone (AMH)
  • ➤ inhibin

questions.text: A 32-year-old P1 woman presents with amenorrhea of 8 months. She gives a history of recurrent early pregnancy losses. On evaluation, she does not respond to the progesterone challenge test. Her FSH is 7, and a UPT (urine pregnancy test) is negative. What is the possible cause of her secondary amenorrhea?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Asherman syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Asherman syndrome is characterized by intrauterine adhesions, often leading to secondary amenorrhea and recurrent pregnancy loss . A lack of response to the progesterone challenge test and normal FSH levels are key diagnostic clues.
  • ➤ Asherman syndrome
  • ➤ secondary amenorrhea
  • ➤ recurrent pregnancy loss
  • ➤ progesterone challenge test

questions.text: What is the characteristic hormonal finding in PCOS?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) LH > FSH

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The characteristic hormonal finding in PCOS is an elevated LH/FSH ratio ( LH > FSH ), which is associated with anovulation, hyperandrogenism, and the clinical manifestations of the syndrome.
  • ➤ PCOS
  • ➤ elevated LH/FSH ratio
  • ➤ LH > FSH

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman has an endometrial thickness of 14 mm with an adnexal mass. A previous report of endometrial biopsy shows complex endometrial hyperplasia with the presence of atypical cells. Why is hysterectomy indicated in her?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Risk of endometrial carcinoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A hysterectomy is indicated in cases of complex endometrial hyperplasia with atypia due to the significant risk of progression to endometrial carcinoma . This is especially important in postmenopausal women or those with additional risk factors such as increased endometrial thickness and adnexal masses.
  • ➤ complex endometrial hyperplasia with atypia
  • ➤ endometrial carcinoma

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman is diagnosed with cervical cancer. Investigations revealed a lesion of 2 cm limited to the cervix. What is the appropriate management?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Type 3 hysterectomy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For early-stage cervical cancer with a lesion ≤2 cm confined to the cervix, a Type 3 radical hysterectomy is the standard treatment. This surgery ensures adequate removal of the tumor along with surrounding tissues and lymph nodes to reduce the risk of recurrence.
  • ➤ cervical cancer
  • ➤ Type 3 radical hysterectomy

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is this procedure beneficial?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Polycystic ovarian syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Laparoscopic ovarian drilling is a surgical option for women with PCOS who do not respond to medical ovulation induction. It helps reduce androgen levels and restore normal ovarian function.
  • ➤ Laparoscopic ovarian drilling
  • ➤ PCOS

questions.text: In a menstrual cycle, the primary oocyte undergoes meiotic division to produce two unequal daughter cells under the influence of the mid-cycle LH surge. What is the cause of the LH surge?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) A rise in estradiol

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The LH surge is triggered by a rise in estradiol from the dominant follicle in the late follicular phase, leading to ovulation. Estradiol exerts a positive feedback effect on the hypothalamus and pituitary, resulting in the release of luteinizing hormone.
  • ➤ LH surge
  • ➤ rise in estradiol

questions.text: A young female who is sexually active presents to the OPD with complaints of lower abdominal pain, bleeding, and foul-smelling vaginal discharge. On examination, she has a fever of 103°F and cervical motion tenderness is present. What is the next best management?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) IV antibiotics

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a sexually active young woman with symptoms of pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) , the immediate management is IV antibiotics to treat the infection and prevent complications. Prompt treatment is crucial to avoid long-term reproductive complications.
  • ➤ pelvic inflammatory disease (PID)
  • ➤ IV antibiotics

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman is diagnosed with an unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy. Identify the most common site of implantation in ectopic pregnancy:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Ampulla

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The ampulla of the fallopian tube is the most common site of implantation in tubal ectopic pregnancies . Early recognition and treatment of ectopic pregnancy are important to prevent complications such as rupture and hemorrhage.
  • ➤ ampulla
  • ➤ tubal ectopic pregnancies

questions.text: A 34-year-old G2 presents at 12 weeks and has been told she has a twin pregnancy. Which of the following can be expected if division of the zygote occurs between 4-8 days after fertilization?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Monochorionic Diamniotic

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In twin pregnancies, monochorionic diamniotic twins occur when the zygote divides between 4-8 days after fertilization. These twins share a single placenta (monochorionic) but have separate amniotic sacs (diamniotic), which is a common configuration in identical twins.
  • ➤ monochorionic diamniotic
  • ➤ 4-8 days

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents to the OPD with complaints of greenish-frothy vaginal discharge for 1 month. Examination reveals the findings shown in the image. On saline microscopy, motile organisms are noticed. What is the best management option?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Metronidazole

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For a patient with symptoms and signs of trichomoniasis , including greenish frothy discharge, strawberry cervix, and motile organisms on microscopy, Metronidazole is the first-line treatment. This infection is a sexually transmitted disease, so partner treatment is also recommended.
  • ➤ trichomoniasis
  • ➤ Metronidazole

questions.text: A 24y primi has delivered 3 days back. She visits the OPD concerned about how long the blood mixed discharge will last.
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 5 days

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lochia rubra , the initial blood-mixed discharge postpartum, typically lasts for about 3-5 days . This is followed by lochia serosa and then lochia alba, with the entire process lasting up to 4-6 weeks postpartum.
  • ➤ Lochia rubra
  • ➤ 3-5 days

questions.text: A 32-year-old P2L2 has had a Cu T 380A inserted in 2023. When should this be replaced?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 2033

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Cu T 380A IUD is a highly effective long-acting reversible contraceptive, which can remain in place and provide contraception for up to 10 years . Therefore, if inserted in 2023, it should be replaced or removed by 2033 .
  • ➤ Cu T 380A
  • ➤ 10 years
  • ➤ 2033

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman complains of inability to conceive, dysmenorrhea, and pelvic pain. An ultrasound shows the following image. Identify the given clinical scenario:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Endometriosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The image and clinical presentation are characteristic of endometriosis , which often presents with pelvic pain , dysmenorrhea , and infertility . The ultrasound image shows a chocolate cyst (endometrioma), a hallmark finding in women with endometriosis.
  • ➤ endometriosis
  • ➤ pelvic pain
  • ➤ dysmenorrhea
  • ➤ infertility
  • ➤ chocolate cyst

questions.text: The most common cause of post-menopausal bleeding is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Senile endometrial atrophy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The most common cause of post-menopausal bleeding is endometrial atrophy . However, due to the possibility of more serious conditions such as endometrial cancer , further evaluation, including transvaginal ultrasound or endometrial biopsy, is recommended in women with post-menopausal bleeding.
  • ➤ post-menopausal bleeding
  • ➤ endometrial atrophy
  • ➤ endometrial cancer

questions.text: A woman who underwent dilatation and curettage following a missed abortion now presents with amenorrhea. Urine pregnancy test is negative. Hysterosalpingography shows the findings seen in the image. What is your diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Asherman syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Asherman syndrome is diagnosed when intrauterine adhesions form after trauma to the uterine lining, such as after dilatation and curettage (D&C). This condition can lead to secondary amenorrhea and is confirmed with imaging techniques like hysterosalpingography , which will show filling defects or adhesions within the uterine cavity.
  • ➤ Asherman syndrome
  • ➤ intrauterine adhesions
  • ➤ secondary amenorrhea
  • ➤ hysterosalpingography
  • ➤ filling defects
  • ➤ adhesions

questions.text: Which of the following can reduce the risk of endometrial cancer in a postmenopausal woman on hormone replacement therapy (HRT)?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Adding progesterone to estrogen

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In postmenopausal women on estrogen replacement therapy , the addition of progesterone significantly reduces the risk of endometrial cancer by counteracting the proliferative effects of estrogen on the endometrium. This is why combined estrogen-progesterone HRT is recommended for women with an intact uterus.
  • ➤ estrogen replacement therapy
  • ➤ progesterone
  • ➤ endometrial cancer
  • ➤ combined estrogen-progesterone HRT

questions.text: What is the best-recommended management in a case of anterior vaginal wall prolapse with cystocele?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Anterior colporrhaphy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The best-recommended management for anterior vaginal wall prolapse with cystocele is anterior colporrhaphy , a surgical procedure aimed at repairing the weakened support structures of the anterior vaginal wall and bladder.
  • ➤ anterior vaginal wall prolapse with cystocele
  • ➤ anterior colporrhaphy

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with severe dysmenorrhea, dyspareunia, and infertility. A diagnosis of endometriosis is made, and during laparoscopy surgery, dense pelvic adhesions with the bowel stuck to the fundus and cystic ovaries adhered to each other are found. What is the next step in managing this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Cystectomy and adhesiolysis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of severe endometriosis with pelvic adhesions and endometriomas , the appropriate surgical management is cystectomy and adhesiolysis . This approach can relieve symptoms and improve fertility, which is particularly important for women of reproductive age.
  • ➤ severe endometriosis
  • ➤ pelvic adhesions
  • ➤ endometriomas
  • ➤ cystectomy and adhesiolysis

questions.text: What is the next best step in a 55-year-old woman who presents with postmenopausal bleeding?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Speculum examination

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a patient with postmenopausal bleeding, the first step is to perform a speculum examination to check for cervical pathology, such as cervical cancer , which is common in this population. If no cervical abnormalities are found, further evaluation with transvaginal ultrasound to assess endometrial thickness is the next step.
  • ➤ speculum examination
  • ➤ cervical cancer
  • ➤ transvaginal ultrasound

questions.text: A young 23-year-old unmarried lady with a BMI of 25 presents with hirsutism. Ultrasonography was done, and the image shown is consistent with the diagnosis. What is the best treatment option for her?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) OCPs

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In young, unmarried women with PCOS , the best treatment to manage symptoms like hirsutism and irregular menstrual cycles is oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) . OCPs reduce androgen levels, regulate menstruation, and help control symptoms associated with PCOS.
  • ➤ PCOS
  • ➤ hirsutism
  • ➤ irregular menstrual cycles
  • ➤ oral contraceptive pills (OCPs)

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman with complaints of a mass per vaginum, as shown in the image, was posted for operative repair. Which of the following procedures is recommended for her?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Ward Mayo surgery

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a postmenopausal woman with a third-degree uterine prolapse , the most appropriate surgical intervention is typically a vaginal hysterectomy with pelvic floor repair, such as the Ward Mayo surgery . This approach resolves the prolapse and restores pelvic floor function. In very elderly or unfit patients, Le Fort's repair may be considered.
  • ➤ third-degree uterine prolapse
  • ➤ vaginal hysterectomy
  • ➤ Ward Mayo surgery
  • ➤ Le Fort's repair

questions.text: In POP Q staging of utero-vaginal prolapse, how many points and measurements are taken?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 9

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The POP-Q system involves taking 9 measurements to quantify pelvic organ prolapse, making it the most precise and standardized method for staging utero-vaginal prolapse.

questions.text: An amniocentesis is done at 20 weeks in a woman whose blood group is B negative. Her husband's blood group is A positive, and an Indirect Coombs' test prior to the procedure was negative. What is the purpose of giving this woman an Anti-D injection?

options.label: A
options.text: To ensure the fetal RBCs do not get destroyed by maternal antibodies

options.label: B
options.text: To neutralize any antibodies that may form by feto maternal hemorrhage

options.label: C
options.text: To neutralize any fetal RBCs that may enter the maternal circulation

options.label: D
options.text: To increase the maternal immune system

questions.correct_answer: C. To neutralize any fetal RBCs that may enter the maternal circulation
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) To neutralize any fetal RBCs that may enter the maternal circulation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Anti-D immunoglobulin is administered to Rh-negative women who are at risk of feto-maternal hemorrhage (such as after procedures like amniocentesis) to neutralize fetal Rh-positive red blood cells that may enter the maternal circulation and prevent the mother from producing antibodies against Rh-positive cells, thereby protecting future pregnancies.
  • ➤ neutralize fetal Rh-positive red blood cells

questions.text: The correct order of events of lactation in the puerperium are: Lactogenesis Mammogenesis Galactopoiesis Galactokinesis
questions.explanation: Ans. D) 2, 1, 4, 3

questions.text: A woman presents with white vaginal discharge. On preparing a vaginal smear, the following are seen. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Candidiasis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The presence of budding yeast and pseudohyphae on a vaginal smear is diagnostic for Candidiasis . It is commonly treated with antifungal medications like fluconazole or topical azoles.
  • ➤ budding yeast
  • ➤ pseudohyphae
  • ➤ Candidiasis

questions.text: An 80-year-old woman complains of leakage of urine on straining and coughing. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Stress urinary incontinence

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Stress urinary incontinence is the involuntary leakage of urine that occurs during activities that increase intra-abdominal pressure, such as coughing, sneezing, or straining. It is more common in elderly women due to pelvic floor weakness.
  • ➤ Stress urinary incontinence

questions.text: Expedited partner treatment is NOT indicated in which of the following infections?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Bacterial vaginosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Expedited partner treatment (EPT) is not indicated for bacterial vaginosis (BV) because it is not an STI and treating male partners does not prevent recurrence in the female. EPT is recommended for Chlamydia , Gonorrhea , and Trichomoniasis to prevent transmission and recurrence.
  • ➤ bacterial vaginosis (BV)
  • ➤ Chlamydia
  • ➤ Gonorrhea
  • ➤ Trichomoniasis

questions.text: Which is not part of Amsel criteria?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Yellowish frothy discharge

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Amsel criteria used for diagnosing bacterial vaginosis include clue cells, a positive whiff test, elevated vaginal pH, and a thin, homogeneous discharge. Yellowish frothy discharge is indicative of Trichomoniasis , not BV.
  • ➤ Amsel criteria
  • ➤ bacterial vaginosis
  • ➤ Yellowish frothy discharge
  • ➤ Trichomoniasis

questions.text: A young girl presented with delayed puberty. On examination, secondary sexual characteristics were absent, the nipples were widely spaced, and she was short in height. The most likely karyotype would be?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 45XO

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The clinical features of Turner syndrome (45XO) include short stature , widely spaced nipples , and delayed puberty due to gonadal dysgenesis. It is the most likely diagnosis in a young girl with these signs, and the karyotype would be 45XO .
  • ➤ Turner syndrome
  • ➤ short stature
  • ➤ widely spaced nipples
  • ➤ delayed puberty
  • ➤ 45XO

questions.text: A multiparous woman from a low socio-economic status, whose husband is a truck driver, is to be screened for cervical cancer. What is the best way to screen for cervical cancer?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) HPV

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ HPV DNA testing is now considered the most effective and preferred method for screening cervical cancer, as it directly detects high-risk HPV strains responsible for the majority of cervical cancer cases. While Pap smears are still widely used, HPV testing is more sensitive and can be especially useful in populations at high risk for cervical cancer.
  • ➤ most effective and preferred method

questions.text: Identify the decidua marked by the arrow
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Decidua basalis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The decidua basalis is the part of the decidua that directly interacts with the developing placenta to provide nutrients and support to the embryo. This forms the maternal side of the placenta.
  • ➤ decidua basalis

questions.text: Which is correct regarding gestational trophoblastic disease?

options.label: A
options.text: Complete mole is triploid, partial mole is diploid

options.label: B
options.text: GTDs include complete mole, partial mole, invasive mole, choriocarcinoma and placental site trophoblastic tumor

options.label: C
options.text: Multi agent chemotherapy is indicated in low risk choriocarcinoma

options.label: D
options.text: Lung metastases indicate a high-risk tumor

questions.correct_answer: B. GTDs include complete mole, partial mole, invasive mole, choriocarcinoma and placental site trophoblastic tumor
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) GTDs include complete mole, partial mole, invasive mole, choriocarcinoma and placental site trophoblastic tumor

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Gestational trophoblastic diseases encompass a range of conditions, including complete and partial moles, invasive mole, choriocarcinoma, and placental site trophoblastic tumor . A complete mole is typically diploid, while a partial mole is triploid. Low-risk choriocarcinoma is treated with single-agent chemotherapy, while lung metastases do not necessarily indicate a high-risk tumor unless accompanied by other risk factors.
  • ➤ Gestational trophoblastic diseases
  • ➤ complete and partial moles, invasive mole, choriocarcinoma, and placental site trophoblastic tumor
  • ➤ Low-risk choriocarcinoma
  • ➤ lung metastases

questions.text: On performing a laparoscopic procedure for an ectopic pregnancy, the following image was seen at the hepatic area. What could have been the possible cause of the ectopic pregnancy?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) PID

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pelvic Inflammatory Disease (PID) can lead to complications such as perihepatic adhesions (Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome) and is a common cause of ectopic pregnancy due to tubal damage and scarring. The image suggests perihepatic adhesions, pointing to PID as the underlying cause.
  • ➤ Pelvic Inflammatory Disease (PID)
  • ➤ perihepatic adhesions (Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome)
  • ➤ ectopic pregnancy

questions.text: A 28-year-old nulligravida presents with primary amenorrhea with secondary sexual characteristics present. She is diagnosed with Müllerian agenesis. During pelvic laparoscopy, what is the expected finding?

options.label: C
options.text: Empty pelvis (no gonads or internal genitalia)

options.label: D
options.text: Bilateral abdominal testes and a small uterus

questions.correct_answer: B. Rudimentary uterus and normal ovaries
questions.explanation:
Ans. B)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In Müllerian agenesis (MRKH syndrome) , there is an absence or underdevelopment of the uterus and upper vagina, but the ovaries are normal and functional, leading to normal secondary sexual characteristics. The typical laparoscopy finding is rudimentary uterus and normal ovaries .
  • ➤ Müllerian agenesis (MRKH syndrome)
  • ➤ normal
  • ➤ rudimentary uterus
  • ➤ normal ovaries

questions.text: During the physical examination for chronic pelvic pain, the technique shown here should be included. Nodularity may be found most commonly with which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Endometriosis or neoplasia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Nodularity during a pelvic examination is most commonly associated with endometriosis or neoplastic conditions , as these can cause fibrosis, adhesions, or masses that are palpable during bimanual examination. This technique is an essential part of the evaluation for chronic pelvic pain.
  • ➤ endometriosis
  • ➤ neoplastic conditions

questions.text: What is the most common medical complaint of women during menopausal transition?

options.label: D
options.text: Vasomotor symptoms characterized as hot flashes

questions.correct_answer: D. Vasomotor symptoms characterized as hot flashes
questions.explanation:
Ans. D)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The most common symptom during the menopausal transition is vasomotor symptoms , characterized by hot flashes and night sweats , which are primarily related to the decline in estrogen levels. These symptoms typically peak during perimenopause and early postmenopause.
  • ➤ menopausal transition
  • ➤ vasomotor symptoms
  • ➤ hot flashes
  • ➤ night sweats

questions.text: A 13-year-old female presents with increasing abdominal pain. She has begun appropriate pubertal development, although menarche has not occurred. During examination, a central abdominopelvic mass is appreciated. Physical examination findings prompt sonography and then magnetic resonance (MR) imaging with contrast. The MR imaging results are shown. Which of the following congenital anomalies is most likely present?

options.label: D
options.text: Obstructed hemivagina and ipsilateral renal anomaly (OHVIRA) syndrome

questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Imperforate hymen

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Imperforate hymen is a congenital anomaly that presents with primary amenorrhea , cyclical abdominal pain , and sometimes urinary retention due to the accumulation of menstrual blood in the vagina ( hematocolpos ). It can be identified on imaging (such as MRI) by the presence of a fluid-filled mass below the uterus, which is consistent with the findings in this case.
  • ➤ Imperforate hymen
  • ➤ primary amenorrhea
  • ➤ cyclical abdominal pain
  • ➤ urinary retention
  • ➤ hematocolpos
